utterances: Because their constituents see the immediate thing.
This is the role of leadership.
The role of leadership is to examine choices and to weigh the pros and cons of each choice.
And I think any responsible leader will see it very clearly that Iraq is a situation that's got to be stabilized and the United States must not walk away from it.
Well, Ambassador Sumaidaie, thank you very much for talking with us.
Thank you.
Samir Sumaidaie is Iraq's ambassador to the United States.
Human rights groups warn that if violence continues in Iraq, the country's neighbors could face a widening refugee crisis.
The United Nations estimates that some 1.4 million Iraqis already have fled to neighboring countries, mostly to Jordan and Syria and some 2000 more leave Iraq every day.
Aquils Fahed(ph) is among those who left.
We reach Fahed by telephone today in Syria.
He's a Shiite and he worked in an Iraqi oil refinery.
But after the war started, he was forced out and threatened with violence.
Everything unstable.
Everything dangerous.
And you cannot go out.
Inside your house, you cannot sleep seriously until morning.
Fahed says he feels safer now in Damascus.
He struggles there to support his wife and four daughters.
The life is very difficult.
We haven't any money.
We haven't any sort of life.
And Aquils Fahed says he sees no possibility of returning to Baghdad.
No, I can't go back to Iraq.
I can't come back to Iraq.
I can't come back to Iraq.
To return to Iraq means simply death.
Even as some Iraqis escape, advocacy groups charge that increasing numbers are being turned back at the borders.
For Iraq's neighbors, the influx of refugees is straining resources.
From Iman, NPR's Eric Westervelt has this report.
Jordan is no stranger to refugee challenges.
Tens of thousands of Palestinians fled to the kingdom during the Arab-Israeli wars.
Last summer, thousands of Lebanese descended on Iman during the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah guerrillas.
Since the start of the war in Iraq in 2003, the UN estimates that 700,000 Iraqis have sought refuge in Jordan.
Twenty-nine-year-old Mustafa Ahmed left the violence of Iraq to work as a day laborer in Jordan's growing underground economy.
(Speaking foreign language).
Williams' big break came a few years later, when he was cast as an alien who drifted to Earth from the planet Ork.
Mork from Ork ended up as the roommate of straight-arrow Mindy McConnell, played by Pam Dawber.
His greeting became a cultural catchphrase.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""MORK AND MINDY"")
(As Mork) Nanu, nanu.
As did his version of an alien expletive.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""MORK AND MINDY"")
(As Mork) Shazbot.
After ""Mork and Mindy,"" Williams would go on to make dozens of movies.
Some were highly praised, such as his role as Russian defector Vladimir Ivanoff in 1984's ""Moscow On The Hudson."" Vladimir ached for America, only to discover it wasn't as perfect as he dreamed.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""MOSCOW ON THE HUDSON"")
(As Vladimir Ivanoff) To tell you the truth, Orlando, New York frightens me.
It's brutal.
It's crazy.
But in the end, Vlad and New York were made for each other.
Williams regaled audiences with one of his most loved roles in ""Mrs.
Doubtfire"" as a divorced husband who dresses in drag so his unsuspecting ex-wife will hire him as their children's nanny.

And he earned an Oscar for his portrayal of tough-love psychiatrist Sean Maguire in 1997's ""Good Will Hunting."" Here, Maguire challenges Will Hunting, an angry math genius who mops floors at MIT, to go after a girl he likes, despite his reservations.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""GOOD WILL HUNTING"")
(As Sean Maguire) You're not perfect, sport.
But let me save you the suspense.
This girl you met, she isn't perfect either.
But the question is whether or not you're perfect for each other.
That's the whole deal.
That's what intimacy is all about.
In a ""60 Minutes"" interview in 1986, Williams credited his success to his dear friend and mentor, comedian Jonathan Winters.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""60 MINUTES"")
Jonathan has just taught me about - the world is open for play.
I mean, he's - that anything and everybody is mockable in wonderful way.
Mockable in a wonderful way - like gently poking fun at one of the most important populations in his adopted hometown.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
San Francisco, where God Save the Queen has a different meaning.
(CHEERING)
Or becoming a comedic tornado in his voiceover role as the decidedly show struck Genie who channels entertainment icons.
Williams' lightning mimicry goes from Arnold Schwarzenegger to Ed Sullivan in the hit Disney animated movie ""Aladdin.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""ALADDIN"")
(As Genie) The ever impressive, the long-contained, the often imitated, but never duplicated, duplicated, duplicated, duplicated, Genie of the Lamp.
Right here, direct from the lamp.
Right here for your very much wish fulfillment.
But it was live on stage where Williams outdid most of his comedic colleagues.
Gilbert Gottfried often did stand up in the same clubs on the same nights as Williams.
He said if he was in the audience or backstage, Williams frequently called him up on stage to improvise with him.
You definitely had your adrenaline going and you couldn't slack off for a second.
Gottfried says his last memory of Williams is a fond one.
They'd both done a benefit with Bob Saget and they'd gone to a small diner for a bite.
Billy Crystal was in town and joined them.
And the three of us went to a little restaurant.
And the middle of the night, we all sat having dessert and talking and laughing.
It was a great, great night.
And a great way, Gottfried says, to remember a gifted, generous man.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
If there ever is an earthquake in San Francisco, it's just God saying, get those condominiums off my back.
Karen Grigsby Bates, NPR News.
To reduce one of the highest rates of fetal alcohol syndrome in the country, bars in Alaska are now offering pregnancy tests.
The pilot program is meant to reach women early in pregnancy, a crucial time when they might not know they're expecting.
From member station KTOO, Casey Kelly has more.
Inside the ladies room at the Peanut Farm bar in Anchorage, a dispenser advertising free pregnancy tests hangs on the wall.
(SOUNDBITE OF WHIRRING)
I press the button to get one of the self-administered urine tests, and on this day, they're all out.
The front of the machine features a poster showing a silhouette of a pregnant woman drinking from a bottle.
The text at the top says remember the last time you had sex?
Aimee Rathbun says she didn't notice the dispenser at first.
